Comments: I was so stoked when I saw the first trailer for  angrybirds 2. This was going to be an incredible sequel and I could not wait to try it out. I am so glad this was not a paid app. Rovio Entertainment really flipped the bird with this one. In all the other  angrybirds games, you can pay for power-ups but the game can be fully played without them. In  angrybirds 2 that is not the case. You can only play so far before you start dishing out more and more money. What I do not understand is why a company as big as Rovio would feel the need to create an app that will require people to pay so much money in order to complete. How could they not see this would eventually hurt them badly?  Dear Rovio Entertainment, Your greed and lust for money will be your downfall very soon if  angrybirds 2 is the kind of garbage you plan on creating from here on out.

Comments: The graphics of  angrybirds 2 is outstanding. The animation is beautiful and the characters are very lively. However, when playing  angrybirds 2 I get the feeling that I'm playing a casino game more than I am playing a mobile phone game, i'm constantly losing for reasons out of my control, many times floating pigs can get into places that you can not reach, The payout versus play is absolutely horrible, forcing you to pay for gems, and The further you get into  levels, The harder the pigs get to kill to the point that rocks can not even kill them  The advertising this game is so thick you would think it's a joke. I do like the catered bonus card advertisements,  very clever, but even those spells feel like they are nerfed.  It feels unbalanced in the way that you have to pay for gems in order to keep advancing it's not fun enough to keep my attention that long I quickly move on to other games.

Comments: There is a terrible crash problem. It often happens during a game and robs me of a life or an opportunity play in the arena.  The game is really slow too, and we need to be able to play the game (arena not included) with no internet access.  The general consensus is that we hate the lives system. Why will not you listen?  Another thing: the levels are not memorable and none of them really stand out, like they did in angrybirds 1.  Everything just seems like a random, frustrating, sluggish and repetitive progression to the next boss fight.  I suppose it's a good thing though that there are no fun levels that we want to repeat, since the lives system would keep us from casually playing them.  A simple fix you could do would be to allow people to play levels that they have already beat without worrying about lives; for repeat levels, just take away the lives and put the retry button back on there! I doubt you would lose any money since nobody replays levels anyway.  On a positive note: I like the graphics, and I've grown accustomed to the card system, though I would prefer to see the whole deck, not just three.  It's interesting that I can level up my birds.  We'll see where that leads.    In conclusion, There's a reason you only got three and a half stars on this game.
lower_comments: there is a terrible crash problem. it often happens during a game and robs me of a life or an opportunity play in the arena.  the game is really slow too, and we need to be able to play the game (arena not included) with no internet access.  the general consensus is that we hate the lives system. why will not you listen?  another thing: the levels are not memorable and none of them really stand out, like they did in angrybirds 1.  everything just seems like a random, frustrating, sluggish and repetitive progression to the next boss fight.  i suppose it's a good thing though that there are no fun levels that we want to repeat, since the lives system would keep us from casually playing them.  a simple fix you could do would be to allow people to play levels that they have already beat without worrying about lives; for repeat levels, just take away the lives and put the retry button back on there! i doubt you would lose any money since nobody replays levels anyway.  on a positive note: i like the graphics, and i've grown accustomed to the card system, though i would prefer to see the whole deck, not just three.  it's interesting that i can level up my birds.  we'll see where that leads.    in conclusion, there's a reason you only got three and a half stars on this game.

Comments: The game has some good aspects, such as the card system where you can choose which bird you want to shoot. Then there the life system. If there was ever a clearer way to show greed. This is it. It completely hinders the player from playing a simple game that really was never that great in the first place, it was just addictive. Now you have to pay a certain amount of money so you can play another five minutes. This is not even the only game with a life/energy system. The only reason for it is so the company can squeeze as much money as they can from you. do not fall for it. It's simply wrong to force this on people who do not want to, but feel like they have to. So to sum it all up, if you enjoyed the first  angrybirds game, hopefully you appreciated that joy, because now it's a joke. This is not a game, it's a slap in the face.

Comments: I can not stand the insatiable greed in the App Store these days. I would happily pay a few bucks for a potentially great game, but the misleading cash grab pay for play on a \free\" game is so annoying they will never get another dollar from me.   They changed the physics to the point where the big bird that smashes through wooden structures like a battering ram gets stopped dead in its tracks by a balloon or tiny pebble. This would be ok to make for more difficult levels, but combined with the removal of the retry ability and then having to pay for additional lives is just insane. What a waste"

Comments: Since the update, I'm more inclined just to delete the app. Not only did they reduce the number of lives, but they added extra puzzles to stages to make them harder and run out of lives quicker. I first noticed on lvl 140. I had been stuck on this level for a bit, it's a boss stage, and went online to watch a vid or get some advice on how to play it to move on. That's when I noticed the tutorial vid only shows a 4 stage level, now it's 5. An added middle stage set up to waste at least 2 birds and make it harder to finish without buying special cards or lives. Also there's a bug in which sometimes you do not get to pick your next bird, it just gives you whatever was next. Will probably delete later.

All in all I am ready to quit playing it all together, because it gets boring when there's no progress to be made and you run out of lives every 5 minutes. Comments: Rovio has succeeded in doing a masterful job of  ...using every crappy freemium gimmick to milk this franchise beyond the point where its fun any more.  The timed lives are pathetic. A game that actually PREVENTS you from playing it too much. Genius! As if the 5 lives was not bad enough, then they changed the max lives you could accumulate to 3! Its almost not even worth waiting for the app to open now.  The random levels and materials are the same reason I stopped playing  angrybirds Stella: Theres no point to winning since its mostly just the luck of the draw on what structures, pig locations, materials, and cards you happen to get.  Which also makes the leaderboard pointless, because some random arrangements are easier than others. You might as well compare PGA tournament scores against mini-golf scores.  In several cases, the random layout has been un-winnable due to a pig randomly being put somewhere where you can not hit him or a structure falls apart by itself because the random materials dont mesh correctly. I actually won a room without flinging a bird because of this.  Of course, they let you buy cheats to get spells to take the skill even further out of the picture, continue the game with additional cards, and buy more lives to keep repeating the levels until you get a good combination of structures, cards, golden bonus birds, etc.  The new bird, Silver, is not too useful for his looping ability. Hes mostly useful as a cleanup bird if you have a pig leftover somewhere.  And the first update adding new levels to a game with random levels was somewhat laughable. Probably a few new layouts and devices, but I havent been interested enough to play up to the new levels yet.  The self-aware pigs sensing when they are about to die are visually interesting, I guess. And an occasional 3D pig splat can be enjoyable, but the freemium gimmicks really take the fun out of this game.  Still playing  angrybirds 2 for now when Im bored and dont have anything else to do, but I doubt Ill keep playing it as much as the other  angrybirds games. The others (except Stella) at least need some skill to win the levels without cheats and they actually feel like you accomplished something when you got 3 stars. Three stars arent that hard to get in  angrybirds 2. Enjoyment is even harder to get out of  angrybirds 2.

game that actually prevents you from playing it too much. genius! as if the 5 lives was not bad enough, then they changed the max lives you could accumulate to 3! its almost not even worth waiting for Comments: I wanted to love this game. The new graphics and game play are awesome, but... Let me pay $1-5 for the game and enjoy it in peace. Instead, you gave in to temptation and went with this crappy Freemium direction and have made the game unplayable unless you pay.  I want to pay. I want to support you as a company with IP that is good, but instead I have deleted your app off my devices and convinced 3 other friends and family to do the same. And a fourth not to install the app. You do not want customers, so now you have lost 5.  How can you ruin yourselves like this, no wonder you've laid off more than a third of your staff in the last few months. Hopefully, when you go under that you will take your IP and release to the Public domain so it can be enjoyed.

Comments: After I continue to trudge through the nightmarish new levels, I no longer believe these guys to be scam artists. No. They're all out crooks. The is no other explanation for things like the smallest pig somehow surviving an entire tower toppling upon them (which always seems to happen conveniently happen when down to your last bird.)  It saddens me, angers me, and make me sick to my stomach that these guys turned into a dirtier version of Candy Crush seemingly overnight.  They essentially cross the line between flipping the script and all out cheating their users in hopes of suckering more cash out of them. Magically, things that would have worked before the update no longer do- notice those little piggies suddenly got a lot tougher? Notice how the spells other than the eagle became a lot less effective- and most of them were not particularly useful to begin with. Also magically, the life count has been reduced from 5 to 3; so you're not only getting less for your money, if your fool enough to give it to them, but an inferior product. I admittedly fell for it once or twice, but there will be no more. Not for this game, and not for Rovio.   There should be no loyalty toward a company that blatantly attempts to milk there customers after so many years. Good by to these piggies. And I do not mean the green ones.    And to hell with Honey Nut Cheerios by association. Though it is fitting that substance-less trash like that would translate perfectly into the useless spell.  Before anyone tries tbe make the capitalism argument, let's not forget the fact that millions of children and adults alike put Rovio on the map with what was a very minimalistic concept.  Flash forward however many years, and they've built themselves an empire, crossing over with the likes of Star Wars and Transformers. You'd think that they'd be a bit more loyal to their legions of fans. But you'd be wrong. As is the case with \ angrybirds Stella,\" Rovio has lured people in with a \"free app.\"   And do not get me wrong, I've never had a problem paying the $.99-$3.99 for  angrybirds, or even a few extra bucks to unlock bonus rounds in \"Seasons\" and \"Star Wars.\" But the pay-per life format that takes over after the free ride is plain greedy. Not only that, but it's a little bit too convenient for them how the script seemingly flips once the free ride comes to an end.  Again, fun game, love the graphics. Just disappointed in Rovio's sudden greed."
lower_comments: after i continue to trudge through the nightmarish new levels, i no longer believe these guys to be scam artists. no. they're all out crooks. the is no other explanation for things like the smallest pig somehow surviving an entire tower toppling upon them (which always seems to happen conveniently happen when down to your last bird.)  it saddens me, angers me, and make me sick to my stomach that these guys turned into a dirtier version of candy crush seemingly overnight.  they essentially cross the line between flipping the script and all out cheating their users in hopes of suckering more cash out of them. magically, things that would have worked before the update no longer do- notice those little piggies suddenly got a lot tougher? notice how the spells other than the eagle became a lot less effective- and most of them were not particularly useful to begin with. also magically, the life count has been reduced from 5 to 3; so you're not only getting less for your money, if your fool enough to give it to them, but an inferior product. i admittedly fell for it once or twice, but there will be no more. not for this game, and not for rovio.   there should be no loyalty toward a company that blatantly attempts to milk there customers after so many years. good by to these piggies. and i do not mean the green ones.    and to hell with honey nut cheerios by association. though it is fitting that substance-less trash like that would translate perfectly into the useless spell.  before anyone tries tbe make the capitalism argument, let's not forget the fact that millions of children and adults alike put rovio on the map with what was a very minimalistic concept.  flash forward however many years, and they've built themselves an empire, crossing over with the likes of star wars and transformers. you'd think that they'd be a bit more loyal to their legions of fans. but you'd be wrong. as is the case with \ angrybirds stella,\" rovio has lured people in with a \"free app.\"   and do not get me wrong, i've never had a problem paying the $.99-$3.99 for  angrybirds, or even a few extra bucks to unlock bonus rounds in \"seasons\" and \"star wars.\" but the pay-per life format that takes over after the free ride is plain greedy. not only that, but it's a little bit too convenient for them how the script seemingly flips once the free ride comes to an end.  again, fun game, love the graphics. just disappointed in rovio's sudden greed."

Comments: It's kind of astonishing how a game could go from pretty entertaining to furiatingly unplayable in the span of 1 update, but Rovio has seemed to accomplished this feat with the recent  angrybirds update.  The physics engine is a joke and employed at Rovio's discretion. I however I think the last straws for me were the trampoline levels and the magician pig, which elements combine to both encourage iPad smashing frustration: the trampolines leave all gameplay to pure luck, no skill is required to plan an attack or winning strategy, and, the magician pig requires wasting anywhere from 1 to all the birds in the deck, forcing endless replay. You literally feel robbed of any gameplay reward.  Games are supposed to be both fun and test skills,  the latest update robs  angrybirds 2 of both of these qualities. And so, sadly, I am going to delete the app.

Comments: Way too hard very quickly for younger players - by level 30, the kids get 5 minutes of repeated losing and then will have to wait for hours or keep paying for another shot (which will likely also last 5 minutes). Earlier games really just required 1 or 2 lucky/well aimed shots, but now you have several phases of needing at least that and so younger players will get stuck.  More experienced angrybirds players might make it farther, but it will get that hard for pretty much all players eventually. The random factor makes some levels just stupid hard - I've had balloon riders + teleporting magicians + multiple shooting pigs in a single level, and if you can not birdie it you will run out before you finish the 5 other levels. I beat the initial 240 levels with only free gem usage, but I have no desire to ever try them again. If you do not get lucky later with the right reinforcements and miss the tricky pigs in bad starting locations, you basically can lose on one phase after 5 phases of perfect play and have to redo them all. Very very frustrating.  It is almost like they want you to lose, or maybe they realize that if they annoy enough people some of them will just try to buy their way through. I guess Free to Play is not Fun to Play.  Great job killing all the good will everyone ever had for you, Rovio!
lower_comments: way too hard very quickly for younger players - by level 30, the kids get 5 minutes of repeated losing and then will have to wait for hours or keep paying for another shot (which will likely also last 5 minutes). earlier games really just required 1 or 2 lucky/well aimed shots, but now you have several phases of needing at least that and so younger players will get stuck.  more experienced angrybirds players might make it farther, but it will get that hard for pretty much all players eventually. the random factor makes some levels just stupid hard - i've had balloon riders + teleporting magicians + multiple shooting pigs in a single level, and if you can not birdie it you will run out before you finish the 5 other levels. i beat the initial 240 levels with only free gem usage, but i have no desire to ever try them again. if you do not get lucky later with the right reinforcements and miss the tricky pigs in bad starting locations, you basically can lose on one phase after 5 phases of perfect play and have to redo them all. very very frustrating.  it is almost like they want you to lose, or maybe they realize that if they annoy enough people some of them will just try to buy their way through. i guess free to play is not fun to play.  great job killing all the good will everyone ever had for you, rovio!

Comments: Revised - F you Rovio!!  Now you lower the amount of starting birds from 10 to 5?  And then you have to buy more lives?  I've got $12 invested in this game already and you want more?!  One star for your greedy selves. Stay away.   What happened to the good old days where you could enjoy any angrybirds level over and over until you mastered it?  Or you could play as long as you wanted without having to spend money to buy more lives?  While this game is certainly fun and addicting, the cost to play after about level 25 becomes outrageous. You need 'spells' to advance (most levels are unbeatable without them) but they are expensive!! You could easily spend $30-$50 and still be feeling the 'stress' of running out of lives and spells both of which require more $$$$$. The cost is so severe it's a -3.   Look - I understand Rovio has to make money - but going from a free platform to a money sucking platform is really a turn off. Maybe charge $9.99 for unlimited play or something like that. Until they do, I am not playing anymore due to how frustratingly expensive gameplay is. It's worth something but not worth this much.

Comments: FYI... 3-starred every level up to the recent update and will probably be calling it quits due to the recent changes and I'm no willing to support their business decisions any longer.  Echoing many of the other reviews on here, the micro transactions and waiting to play can be quite aggravating. I can get over those, though. What disappoints me most about this sequel is the trial and error skills they promoted so heavily in versions past are all but gone.  1 - the starting order of your birds is never the same: this eliminates the strategy of being able to use the birds to the best of their abilities against whatever towers are in a level's section.  2 - the sections within each level are never the same: the general shape and locations of the towers are close and fall within whatever parameters Rovio has decided to implement.   3 - the pigs in the level are never the same: one will float out of harm's way initially; one will throw things at you making your bird go off course; one will turn your bird into something useless; there are others (and they are apparently going to keep adding more if the recent update is any indication).  I'm sad that it had to be this way.
lower_comments: fyi... 3-starred every level up to the recent update and will probably be calling it quits due to the recent changes and i'm no willing to support their business decisions any longer.  echoing many of the other reviews on here, the micro transactions and waiting to play can be quite aggravating. i can get over those, though. what disappoints me most about this sequel is the trial and error skills they promoted so heavily in versions past are all but gone.  1 - the starting order of your birds is never the same: this eliminates the strategy of being able to use the birds to the best of their abilities against whatever towers are in a level's section.  2 - the sections within each level are never the same: the general shape and locations of the towers are close and fall within whatever parameters rovio has decided to implement.   3 - the pigs in the level are never the same: one will float out of harm's way initially; one will throw things at you making your bird go off course; one will turn your bird into something useless; there are others (and they are apparently going to keep adding more if the recent update is any indication).  i'm sad that it had to be this way.

Comments: Enjoyed playing the game and I am in the level 120 range. Had a few issues getting into the daily arena. Then I began to notice that my scores in the arena was no where close to whatever those top 3 individuals were scoring. I was in the top three in my league most of the time so how did I become such a poor player all of a sudden? Then I figured that I would need to buy a bunch of the Eagles and other boosters to even come close to the top scores to earn extra feathers. That is just not right.   In my opinion the changes to game play, difficulty, and problems getting through some levels without boosters is because of greed.   As they say in the movies, \"buh bye\" to this game!   My advice is do not waste your time unless you want to spend money to get through the impossible levels."

Comments: Despite so many 1 star reviews due to the lives system they update the game reducing the lives from 5 to 3 and lengthen the time it takes to get a life back from 30mins to an hour. Rovio - you suck.  Pity you can not give zero stars. Not that it's a bad game. It's just not challenging. Each level is randomly generated and getting three stars is the norm. The so called boss levels are often the easiest of the lot with one bird able to send the boss pig flying out of the level for an instant win. Earning income from advertising is fine - they're not in it for love... and watching an ad to get extra lives, an extra bird to finish a level, or another go in the daily tournament is also fine. But now an ad has started to pop up between levels. Lame. The game is broken and buggy (what was the pre-release for if it still launched with bugs?). But back to the challenge.  angrybirds was legendary level design. Often getting 3 stars took the perfect use of each bird and good aiming. Now it's random birds, random power ups, random levels. It's a lazy game that shows Rovio have finally sold out. Likely richer than they ever dreamed possible, but now giving us less for more. Their legacy will be a game that broke the mold and became a pop culture classic, followed by a sequel that highlights everything wrong with mobile gaming, and how greed corrupts.
lower_comments: despite so many 1 star reviews due to the lives system they update the game reducing the lives from 5 to 3 and lengthen the time it takes to get a life back from 30mins to an hour. rovio - you suck.  pity you can not give zero stars. not that it's a bad game. it's just not challenging. each level is randomly generated and getting three stars is the norm. the so called boss levels are often the easiest of the lot with one bird able to send the boss pig flying out of the level for an instant win. earning income from advertising is fine - they're not in it for love... and watching an ad to get extra lives, an extra bird to finish a level, or another go in the daily tournament is also fine. but now an ad has started to pop up between levels. lame. the game is broken and buggy (what was the pre-release for if it still launched with bugs?). but back to the challenge.  angrybirds was legendary level design. often getting 3 stars took the perfect use of each bird and good aiming. now it's random birds, random power ups, random levels. it's a lazy game that shows rovio have finally sold out. likely richer than they ever dreamed possible, but now giving us less for more. their legacy will be a game that broke the mold and became a pop culture classic, followed by a sequel that highlights everything wrong with mobile gaming, and how greed corrupts.

Comments: Unfortunately, Rovio has fallen victim to a desire to assimilate with the microtransaction era of gaming, presenting us with a deeply broken lives system that does not at all fit with the way people are used to playing  angrybirds.  Although lives may work for games like Candy Crush Saga,  angrybirds cannot sustain itself with one, as players can not afford to fluff a shot and instantly restart as they were once able to.   On the plus side, the game looks beautiful, and plays as good as ever. The multi-stage levels seem a bit pointless, and the boss fights are fairly repetitive, but altogether it's still the  angrybirds most people love, despite the ridiculous addition of lives to net more profit for Rovio
lower_comments: unfortunately, rovio has fallen victim to a desire to assimilate with the microtransaction era of gaming, presenting us with a deeply broken lives system that does not at all fit with the way people are used to playing  angrybirds.  although lives may work for games like candy crush saga,  angrybirds cannot sustain itself with one, as players can not afford to fluff a shot and instantly restart as they were once able to.   on the plus side, the game looks beautiful, and plays as good as ever. the multi-stage levels seem a bit pointless, and the boss fights are fairly repetitive, but altogether it's still the  angrybirds most people love, despite the ridiculous addition of lives to net more profit for rovio

Comments: Gameplay itself is excellent but the entire game is completely ruined - you only have 5 lives and when you've used those Rovio want your money to keep playing. It's either that, or wait half an hour, or watch a video to get one extra life. All this completely takes away from the enjoyment and fluidity of the game. Charge a one off fee to buy the game and stop the greed, it makes your game an unpleasant experience and worthy of deletion.

Comments: A one star review may seem harsh but the lives/gems system has tainted  angrybirds 2 to the point that I just do not want to play it anymore.  This is a massive shame because the  angrybirds  gameplay is a proven formula and Rovio made some genius improvements in the aesthetic and gameplay.   The graphics are so gorgeous and the animations of the birds and pigs are adorable. But beside that, the best improvements are the stage splitting and the new card system that allows you to select which bird you want to fling. These things are exactly what this game needed to keep it as fresh yet familiar and extremely addictive as ever.  But they screwed up.   Rovio decided to go with a horrible freemium trope and lock you out unless you pay to play after 5 fails. They even have the nerve to call their in game currency the very predictable 'gems', as if no creativity at all went into this gross exploitation.  This system is flawed and I wish they would return to the old model of having a free SD Version with ads and occasional videos and a paid HD version.
lower_comments: a one star review may seem harsh but the lives/gems system has tainted  angrybirds 2 to the point that i just do not want to play it anymore.  this is a massive shame because the  angrybirds  gameplay is a proven formula and rovio made some genius improvements in the aesthetic and gameplay.   the graphics are so gorgeous and the animations of the birds and pigs are adorable. but beside that, the best improvements are the stage splitting and the new card system that allows you to select which bird you want to fling. these things are exactly what this game needed to keep it as fresh yet familiar and extremely addictive as ever.  but they screwed up.   rovio decided to go with a horrible freemium trope and lock you out unless you pay to play after 5 fails. they even have the nerve to call their in game currency the very predictable 'gems', as if no creativity at all went into this gross exploitation.  this system is flawed and i wish they would return to the old model of having a free sd version with ads and occasional videos and a paid hd version.

Comments: Not long ago, if you wanted a game you'd simply purchase it and play to your hearts content.  The only delay would be downloading and installing.  This version has amazing graphics and well, that's about it.  It takes forever to load, then once you click on the level you'd like to play it takes another time zone to load.  Then you can start enjoying! - nope. If you fail a level, you have to restart after a long wait- unless you would like to buy more garbage to proceed.  Once you click the restart button the app crashes. Over and over.  So if you want to wait forever to play a game that you have to constantly fork out for and that crashes every time you want to play more than three minutes worth, this is the one for you.

Comments: I played about 8 to 10 levels of the game before deleting it. It game itself plays well and is designed nicely, but nothing else about it is worth the download. I'm not the first to say it and I will not be the last, Rovio sold out, and lost my respect at the same time. They've sold their souls to the \free to play\" cash grab format that so many other games are using more and more, to line the developer's pockets. The direct sequel to the extremely popular first instalment in the  angrybirds franchise. It's very disappointing and near impossible to play and enjoy it due to the shrinking life timer and you have to pay money to continue. Why Rovio?"

Comments: Sure it's free, sure you can play the full game without paying a dime... but the recent update has gone too far, proving that mobile gaming is just another cash-grab for developers. Instead of 10 hearts you now have 5, shortening your free game time (otherwise, if you wanna play again right away, you're gonna have to pay up). The ads are constant, repetitive, and just plain awkward to watch when all you want to do is PLAY the damn game. I had respect for Rovio when the first few  angrybirds games came out. You had to pay a dollar or something for each game but at least you had the full game, without any ads or in-app restrictions. Now, it's clear that even Rovio has become just another group of sellouts. Stay away from \free\" games, it's sad to see them take over the App Store without any kind of substance or creativity put in them."
lower_comments: sure it's free, sure you can play the full game without paying a dime... but the recent update has gone too far, proving that mobile gaming is just another cash-grab for developers. instead of 10 hearts you now have 5, shortening your free game time (otherwise, if you wanna play again right away, you're gonna have to pay up). the ads are constant, repetitive, and just plain awkward to watch when all you want to do is play the damn game. i had respect for rovio when the first few  angrybirds games came out. you had to pay a dollar or something for each game but at least you had the full game, without any ads or in-app restrictions. now, it's clear that even rovio has become just another group of sellouts. stay away from \free\" games, it's sad to see them take over the app store without any kind of substance or creativity put in them."

Comments: The whole point of why  angrybirds was successful was because you could play continuously and simply enjoy the game. With the introduction of the hearts (more like roadblocks) it's all too clear Rovio is more concerned about making money off their clients then keeping them happy with their product. Animations were great, so was the gameplay. However, uninstalled because I would rather play a lesser quality game then waste my time waiting for hearts or watching ads to accumulate gems. I hope they actually go through these reviews and learn that the reason they were so successful with their first game is because it seemed like they actually cared about their player's level of enjoyment, not how much they could squeeze out of them while using the game as an incentive for purchases.

Comments: I would prefer an update to the original game with a few options, like turning off the hints. I have no intention on spending a cent on this game, so once the free gem rewards run out, that will be it. I have bought several angrybirds games and would prefer to pay for the game up front. I will not fall for Rovio's money grab attempt.  This game is very loud and obnoxious. As others have said, it's a re-release of Under Pigstruction, which I played for only a couple of minutes.  I am an older person and I have difficulties aiming, so I often have to try a level several times before I get a good score and clear the level. This game penalizes people like me.  It's a shame Rovio is ruining a good series.

Comments: angrybirds 2 has added freemium gimmicks that significantly impedes the addictive nature of its predecessor. The game has sharp, clean graphics and the gameplay is well designed. I also like the ability to choose to watch ads for bonuses instead of having them shoved down my throat. The original  angrybirds allowed for repeating levels until one gained mastery. The addition of lives and the randomization of birds/levels takes that addicting fun away. I quickly found myself bored. I think I will delete  angrybirds 2 and install its more fun, older sibling.

What was very surprising was that this game did not do the same as other games, but instead the Candy Crush method; horrible life system, 90% need to pay, Facebook, ads, and a weird level style. You also have cards and. Different parts. Which is horrible a bad decision, because you can not really get a tactic, since it changes up each time. You wait 30 minutes, for 1 measly life, and to play a horrible and Candy Cursh game.  angrybirds Movie is seriously literally only for money, because Rovio is plummeting horribly. Comments: The positive: Awesome graphics and animations, great new powers for the birds. The negative: Play it a little and youll see how the game tries to make everything impossible unless you spend a boatload of money to buy gems and lives. Fall on a somewhat difficult level, and youll quickly lose all your lives and have to wait hours or spend a lot before being allowed to try again. While I would gladly pay even 5 or 10 dollars for the game, I wont accept being nickel-and-dimed to this extent. Deleted.

Comments: In my original review, I quite enjoyed this game. But as you progress it becomes clearer and clearer, that the only way to enjoy this game to its full potential is to constantly purchase gems and whatever else there is to buy. You can only earn a few gems a day as far as I can tell. While just one special item to help move forward costs, at the lowest, 20 gems! The pigs become increasingly spread out to add challenge, which I enjoy, but it has gotten to the point where you can tell unless you get a lucky shot you pretty well have to rely on a purchase just to get by.   I'm sorry but I would much rather pay a few bucks and get the full deal like in the predecessor to this BULL*HIT way of sucking money out of your faithful customers and fans. I hope by chance this review is read by at least a few people, and you do not support what they have done to our favourite angry little fellas.   You can read the original review and see how much my opinion changed. Thanks for reading.  \Great game so far. Fun new animations and the like. Warning to iPad mini users I experienced game crashes after I installed the game without restarting. Make sure you restart your iPad before playing the first time! 4 stars for the pay to play style unless you wait for hearts.. Good game other wise.\""

Comments: Firstly the good bits - the graphics are excellent and the mechanics are spot on-site feeling even more accurate than the original series.  But the bad far outweighs the good. Whereas the original series had handcrafted levels where you really had to think about how to solve them, this game is an endless series of backgrounds with the same towers being built at random. You are completely dependent on the three birds randomly presented to you at each stage.  I've played over 100 levels and it just feels like more and more of the same.  And the latest update has added unskippable adverts when you compete a level for the first time. Sorry, Rovio, but that's the straw that broke the piggy's back - I'm removing the game from my phone.
lower_comments: firstly the good bits - the graphics are excellent and the mechanics are spot on-site feeling even more accurate than the original series.  but the bad far outweighs the good. whereas the original series had handcrafted levels where you really had to think about how to solve them, this game is an endless series of backgrounds with the same towers being built at random. you are completely dependent on the three birds randomly presented to you at each stage.  i've played over 100 levels and it just feels like more and more of the same.  and the latest update has added unskippable adverts when you compete a level for the first time. sorry, rovio, but that's the straw that broke the piggy's back - i'm removing the game from my phone.

Comments: Following the most recent update whereby the number of lives were reduced from 5 to 3, I am compelled to write this review. This game, while bringing visual and some gameplay improvements, is precisely engineered at every turn to trick you into buying more game time. An easy intro quickly turns into borderline impossible levels that require you to gem up if you want to proceed (or of course, watch a 30-second advert). Oh, and even if you watch those ads and spend money on gems, you still get ads thrown at you randomly. Horrible, awful, greedy behaviour from Rovio.

Comments: The original  angrybirds, and all the other spin offs (Star Wars etc) were brilliant. This one is absolutely awful.  The fact you have to pay for more lives says enough in a nutshell. Yes, companies cannot operate without some sort of income, but this game has been built around the philosophy \MAKE MONEY\". What a shame.  Also, what on earth are those new graphics? They're hideous, what made  angrybirds was the simplicity of it, and the instant loading of levels without all the flash graphics. Now waiting for levels to load and having to watch stupid animations constantly is just irritating.  The fun of  angrybirds came from working out how to do each level. Yes it was frustrating, but the game would not work without the frustration, so everybody enjoyed the feeling when you worked out how to complete a level. Now it is just boring and too jazzed up.   DO NOT DOWNLOAD. RUBBISH."

Comments: The original  angrybirds was a deceptively simple yet fun and addictive game. There could be frustrations but much of the enjoyment came from retrying levels and working out the best way to approach things and get the highest score often using trial and error. The levels had a logic and consistency that allowed you to have fun.   angrybirds 2 has been principally designed to make money. The levels lack consistency, logic and certain elements have been introduced for no other reason than to make it harder to win without paying (pigs randomly floating off on a balloon Im looking at you). Often you are completely reliant on luck and with limited lives/ constant adverts this is hugely frustrating.   The game designers have started with how they can squeeze money out of players and built the game around that rather than making a fun game and then adding extra paid for elements for those who want them. They are essentially saying pay us money to make the game less frustrating and unfair- that is not a selling point and is a frankly repellant business model. Surely if they had just made another fun game and charged upfront for it they could have made enough money (a game this simple shouldnt cost that much to develop).  This game deserves to fail.

Comments: I am a big fan of  angrybirds but this game is disappointing. It needs an internet connection to even start, bombards you with ads and now has limited lives so when you get to a tricky level you have to stop playing and wait for 30 mins (or pay ). It seems to have copied all the annoying parts of Candy Crush Saga and thus ruined the game.   The levels also change when you replay them making it even harder to conquer them as you quickly run out of lives. Some of the pigs randomly create balloons and float away. It all seems like a cynical attempt to extract money from you.  I would gladly pay a few quid to play this game without the life limits, ads etc. Id even pay a little for each set of add on levels but the constant annoyance of the current approach means Ive deleted it.   Sorry Rovio, this game is a failure.

Comments: Ive been an  angrybirds fan since the first game and have played many of the sequels. As you can imagine I was looking forward to playing  angrybirds 2 when it was released and after spending some time with the game there are several things I dont like about it.  Firstly, the in-app purchase model. Im not a fan of in-app purchases and would have preferred if the game was a one off charge of 79p like some of the earlier games have been in the past. I dont mind in-app purchases per se, I was one of the first to pay 69p as an in-app purchase at the time to get unlimited use of the Mighty Eagle in the original game. But things have gone downhill since then and everything is geared towards getting you to spend more on gems, as with many other games sadly. You can still play  angrybirds 2 without spending money as the developer claims but having that option front and centre youre consciously aware of it all the time.  On top of in-app purchases, youre now prompted to watch in-game ads in order to get free extra birds, extra plays in the Arena or to get an extra life, etc. Ive even noticed recently that after completing a level I sometimes get shown a video ad for no apparent reason. I didnt ask for it and it shouldnt be necessary to bombard players with video ads, especially if you havent tapped anything to initiate the video playback in the first place.  Ive also noticed changes in the way many of the birds play. As an example, the blue bird is particularly good at breaking through blue glass objects, but in previous games could also smash wood if need to and if used correctly. In  angrybirds 2 it seems that the blue bird cant even make a dent in wood any more. Similarly, the yellow bird is the king at smashing through wood, but on occasion I would need to use him to smash through glass, which could be done. Now you wouldnt stand a chance, firing Chuck at a glass block will be a waste of bird ammo.  Ive also had issues with the Arena, a part of the game that I play a lot and like the addition of this new feature. I quite often get the number 1 spot enabling me to level up my army of birds. But I have noticed that something strange is happening, I can be at the number 1 spot seconds before the Arena ends and refreshes for the day, then all of a sudden I get awarded feathers to level up and told that I came in 8th place! Whats that all about? Its happened several times, I can be in the top spot by a country mile only to be awarded feathers the second it starts over for the next day and to then be demoted instantly. Today I happened to move from 3rd to 2nd place, which Im not complaining about but I have no idea how that can even happen.  I do like a lot about the game, the fact that you can now choose which bird you use from a possible three is a big help as you progress through the various rooms. As I mentioned the Arena is my favourite feature, pitting you against other players to level up your birds. I also like the different power-ups that you can select at the beginning of a level but again this is something you may eventually have to pay for by forking out for in-game gems to buy them. The graphics, sounds and animations have all improved over the original game and something that makes this game worthwhile playing.  The fact that yet another developer is trying to cram their game full of in-app purchases and video ads just goes to show that they dont care about the customer. Think back to the original  angrybirds, a 69p purchase with no ads, there was originally one in-app purchase giving unlimited use of the Mighty Eagle for those that wanted to gain feathers on every level and that was it. Why couldnt  angrybirds 2 follow that model? Oh sorry, its all about greed, profits and trying to please the people who run the business. Companies in this day and age seem to care very little about their customers rolling out stupid ideas and Im sad to say that this is one of them.
lower_comments: ive been an  angrybirds fan since the first game and have played many of the sequels. as you can imagine i was looking forward to playing  angrybirds 2 when it was released and after spending some time with the game there are several things i dont like about it.  firstly, the in-app purchase model. im not a fan of in-app purchases and would have preferred if the game was a one off charge of 79p like some of the earlier games have been in the past. i dont mind in-app purchases per se, i was one of the first to pay 69p as an in-app purchase at the time to get unlimited use of the mighty eagle in the original game. but things have gone downhill since then and everything is geared towards getting you to spend more on gems, as with many other games sadly. you can still play  angrybirds 2 without spending money as the developer claims but having that option front and centre youre consciously aware of it all the time.  on top of in-app purchases, youre now prompted to watch in-game ads in order to get free extra birds, extra plays in the arena or to get an extra life, etc. ive even noticed recently that after completing a level i sometimes get shown a video ad for no apparent reason. i didnt ask for it and it shouldnt be necessary to bombard players with video ads, especially if you havent tapped anything to initiate the video playback in the first place.  ive also noticed changes in the way many of the birds play. as an example, the blue bird is particularly good at breaking through blue glass objects, but in previous games could also smash wood if need to and if used correctly. in  angrybirds 2 it seems that the blue bird cant even make a dent in wood any more. similarly, the yellow bird is the king at smashing through wood, but on occasion i would need to use him to smash through glass, which could be done. now you wouldnt stand a chance, firing chuck at a glass block will be a waste of bird ammo.  ive also had issues with the arena, a part of the game that i play a lot and like the addition of this new feature. i quite often get the number 1 spot enabling me to level up my army of birds. but i have noticed that something strange is happening, i can be at the number 1 spot seconds before the arena ends and refreshes for the day, then all of a sudden i get awarded feathers to level up and told that i came in 8th place! whats that all about? its happened several times, i can be in the top spot by a country mile only to be awarded feathers the second it starts over for the next day and to then be demoted instantly. today i happened to move from 3rd to 2nd place, which im not complaining about but i have no idea how that can even happen.  i do like a lot about the game, the fact that you can now choose which bird you use Comments: I gave it 2 stars for the graphics, and gameplay experience once the game will actually let you play.  Otherwise, the game is focused purely on making money on in-app purchases, or forcing you to watch ads.  You can not restart a level without buying extra birds or watching a 30 min video (?!)  You can not start the game without internet connection   There's no way to get the bonus cards, other than buying them  And generally, the game keeps harnessing you to sign in and share on social media, buy extra content etc etc...  Essentially, you spend more time cancelling and dismissing purchase suggestions and ads, than you do playing the game.  I got fed up after a day, and deleted it. Would rather pay one off and enjoy playing it.  Shame, as gameplay has potential.

Comments: For me, this game loses too much of the original magic:  1. You have 5 lives, which you lose when you fail to complete all zones in a given level.  It takes time (or money to skip time) to replenish to allow you to re-attack.  This makes 3 starring much harder on the higher levels as you have to wait an hour for them to replenish.  This means you cannot use this app to whittle away your boredom as youll likely run out of lives in 5 mins on higher levels and be bored again whilst waiting.  2. Due to the constant attempts to force ads down our throats, when on poor network connections it is awful.  Ads to get an extra bird to try and complete a level.  Ads to get extra bonuses.  Ads sporadically for no discernible reason.  For mercy sake, I have heard of all of the apps that are being advertised.  If I wanted them I would have got them.  Advertisers really are wasting their money.  So I thought Id turn off network access?  Nice try, but certain features require network access - like this new league feature.    Pointless Suggestion: Get rid of this lives notion and for goodness sake remove the Ads.  I know you want to make money, so just have a paid for version of the game.   3. Takes forever to login and has had repeated crashes.  They seem to fix them but still intermittent issues.  God help you if you have less than perfect network connection too - you are going to be sitting at splash screens for a long time.  Quite why I need to Log In every time I open the app is beyond me.  Pointless Suggestion: Only use network connection when using network features.  If I want to play a normal level then no network access should be required, and no logging in.  4. For some unknown reason it seems to double fire birds way too frequently.  i.e. pull back bird in the slingshot, let go and time the activation of their ability, and  wait whats the second bird now doing in mid-air????  Guess thats this level failed then :/  Ill give it another go oh wait, Ive run out of lives   Pointless Suggestion: Play your app before releasing?!    No wonder Rovio is laying off staff.  This has taken what could be a great game and turned it into a desperate money grabbing attempt.  So very disappointing.  :O

Comments: A good game ruined by excessive monetisation.   Firstly, this game itself is good, not brilliant but definitely good. If you have played  angrybirds before you will be familiar with how it works. The animations are slick and it looks great.   However, there are many obvious money making ploys which have totally soured it for me. Firstly, the number of lives. Five was bad but reducing it to three in the latest update... wow. Secondly, the times that a pig will 'randomly' decide to inflate a balloon and float above the playing area make it impossible to take the game seriously. Thirdly, the levels keep changing, what is all that about? Fourthly, how many adverts?!?   I understand that a lot of time and money has been spent on developing and marketing the game, and people need to earn a salary. However, this is excessive. I would happily pay 2.99 for this game as an in app purchase or whatever, not micro payments for extra lives or other such rubbish like gems.   What a shame the game is how it is with the monetisation avenues everywhere. It spoils what would have been a worthy successor to the original  angrybirds.
lower_comments: a good game ruined by excessive monetisation.   firstly, this game itself is good, not brilliant but definitely good. if you have played  angrybirds before you will be familiar with how it works. the animations are slick and it looks great.   however, there are many obvious money making ploys which have totally soured it for me. firstly, the number of lives. five was bad but reducing it to three in the latest update... wow. secondly, the times that a pig will 'randomly' decide to inflate a balloon and float above the playing area make it impossible to take the game seriously. thirdly, the levels keep changing, what is all that about? fourthly, how many adverts?!?   i understand that a lot of time and money has been spent on developing and marketing the game, and people need to earn a salary. however, this is excessive. i would happily pay 2.99 for this game as an in app purchase or whatever, not micro payments for extra lives or other such rubbish like gems.   what a shame the game is how it is with the monetisation avenues everywhere. it spoils what would have been a worthy successor to the original  angrybirds.

Comments: Well,  angrybirds 2 is decidedly underwhelming. Sure, it looks nice now with some great graphics and slick animation, but it didnt need it. All we needed was more of the old   The decision to add the lives element is really very annoying if you run out of lives, you either watch a 30 second ad, wait until the timer ends or BUY MORE GEMS deep joy. Id have happily paid to download the app in order to not have this happen.   Now, we also get three stages per level. Okay, it makes it a bit different, but entirely pointless (just have a new level?!). Another new feature is that you can now pick which bird (or card??) to fire. In theory this should make it easier, but also takes away the puzzle of trying to work out how the game designers planned each stage to be completed, and just something else that wasnt needed. Also, each time you retry a level, the blocks seem to randomly change wtf?!   The gameplay seems much slower and more broken up/interrupted this time with all the improvements, and on my 5s it seems to take ages to load up.   This used to be a fun, simple and highly addictive game. Now its just boring, over-complicated and irritating.   Shame. I cant even be bothered to even *try* to finish it. I think Ill delete it and just replay the original. One of my favourite games completely ruined by the rise of the Freemium model,and playing with a formula that wasnt broken. If you loved the original, its quite likely you wont like what theyve done with it.   At least I suppose as a Freemium' game I didnt have to pay to find out it was this dull, so there is that

Comments: Nonstop crashing every time I try to play a level. I played from 1-112, and every single time I tried to enter the level, the game crashed. Eventually, after 15 or so crashes, the level MIGHT load. If not, it would continue to crash for the rest of my attempts. Furthermore, the game structure has adopted a lives system designed to pressure you into microtransactions. Loss of a level (which will happen a lot, considering the great difficulty in later levels) will result in you needing 60 gems to finish the level if you so wish to. 60 gems takes a long time to accumulate, and paying 60 damn gems for 3 birds to use in ONE level is a gross overcharge. A single life takes almost 30 minutes to recharge, and you are given 5 lives. Run out of lives? do not want to pay for more? Then you'll be waiting 150 minutes in total for a full set of 5 lives.
lower_comments: nonstop crashing every time i try to play a level. i played from 1-112, and every single time i tried to enter the level, the game crashed. eventually, after 15 or so crashes, the level might load. if not, it would continue to crash for the rest of my attempts. furthermore, the game structure has adopted a lives system designed to pressure you into microtransactions. loss of a level (which will happen a lot, considering the great difficulty in later levels) will result in you needing 60 gems to finish the level if you so wish to. 60 gems takes a long time to accumulate, and paying 60 damn gems for 3 birds to use in one level is a gross overcharge. a single life takes almost 30 minutes to recharge, and you are given 5 lives. run out of lives? do not want to pay for more? then you'll be waiting 150 minutes in total for a full set of 5 lives.

Comments: The levels vary on repeat attempts so it's hard to actually be skilful, which leaves most scores down to luck. A worrying trend towards the candy crush model of portable games where your number of attempts outweighs how good actually are at the game. A lack of a paid version of the app is also a downside. The adverts make the app feel cluttered and cheap.   Also, some levels are very obviously more difficult (109+) in a clear attempt to force users to pay for power ups etc.   I used to associate Rovio with quality apps, but they've just cashed out. The quicker they fade in irrelevance the better.

Comments: Lots of people complaining about IAP here.  I'm not going to join that mob since I've just completed the first 240 levels without touching IAP.  I'm not even going to get into the timer argument. How often have you played a game & thought, \Damn, I need to stop playing now\". Timers make you remember to stop for a moment & continue living. So, no issues there.  My problem however is the lack of variety. You may already know but levels have a random element to them in how they're presented to you.  Trouble is, by the 50th level you'll feel like you've seen some structures before. By the 100th level, you'll feel like you've seen some combinations of structures already. By level 150, you'll feel like you've seen both combinations of structures & base level layouts before (All levels are laid out on 'struts' so there's never an actual floor) & by 200 you'll be yawning at the concept of doing \"this level again\".  It's a shame really, because all other aspects of the game are great. The presentation is top notch, the pigs characteristics are great fun to watch. You'll love how they react to being aimed at, being on a toppling tower & chatting to each other. The audio is another area of vast improvement. Again, it's fun, sounds beefy (In good headphones), I love the stereo affect (Again, headphones) & I really enjoy how the pigs voices change as they fall off the screen or fly towards you & past your head."
lower_comments: lots of people complaining about iap here.  i'm not going to join that mob since i've just completed the first 240 levels without touching iap.  i'm not even going to get into the timer argument. how often have you played a game & thought, \damn, i need to stop playing now\". timers make you remember to stop for a moment & continue living. so, no issues there.  my problem however is the lack of variety. you may already know but levels have a random element to them in how they're presented to you.  trouble is, by the 50th level you'll feel like you've seen some structures before. by the 100th level, you'll feel like you've seen some combinations of structures already. by level 150, you'll feel like you've seen both combinations of structures & base level layouts before (all levels are laid out on 'struts' so there's never an actual floor) & by 200 you'll be yawning at the concept of doing \"this level again\".  it's a shame really, because all other aspects of the game are great. the presentation is top notch, the pigs characteristics are great fun to watch. you'll love how they react to being aimed at, being on a toppling tower & chatting to each other. the audio is another area of vast improvement. again, it's fun, sounds beefy (in good headphones), i love the stereo affect (again, headphones) & i really enjoy how the pigs voices change as they fall off the screen or fly towards you & past your head."

Comments: A bunch of out of control & unstable birds set out to massacre thousands of young pigs because of a few eggs going missing. Blaming all pig kind for this incident, the gang - which includes a suicide bomber bird and a roid head - attack the pigs relentlessly and destroy their homes. The pigs themselves love farting, burping and giggle to themselves, putting up no opposition to the evil birds war machine. They look genuinely terrified of their feathered foes when in the crosshairs and their only defence is to hide themselves well inside breeze blocks, escape on balloons or use their teddy bear gun.   Great addictive game, decent graphics and animation but dont quite agree with the birds plight so only gets 4 stars
lower_comments: a bunch of out of control & unstable birds set out to massacre thousands of young pigs because of a few eggs going missing. blaming all pig kind for this incident, the gang - which includes a suicide bomber bird and a roid head - attack the pigs relentlessly and destroy their homes. the pigs themselves love farting, burping and giggle to themselves, putting up no opposition to the evil birds war machine. they look genuinely terrified of their feathered foes when in the crosshairs and their only defence is to hide themselves well inside breeze blocks, escape on balloons or use their teddy bear gun.   great addictive game, decent graphics and animation but dont quite agree with the birds plight so only gets 4 stars

Comments: What a sad day. The once great  angrybirds, king of the App Store reduced to being the same as every other game out there. But only by the deplorable trend of IAP's to allow you to continue.   The game looks and feels great but it's completely lost the one thing that made  angrybirds: replayability. I can remember spending hours on an individual level trying to get 3 stars or the 100% with the mighty eagle. Now I get 5 go's and then have to wait an extraordinary amount of time to play again. Unless I pay. Sorry Rovio, that will not be happening. I would've paid good money for a new version of the old  angrybirds but now you've lost me. This game took used to take all of my time on long haul flights and when commuting but now I'm afraid Rovio, as soon as that last life went, you lost me and  angrybirds 2 will not be played again. I want to decide when I play a game, not someone else decide for me.  What a waste of the best game ever to be on the App Store.

Comments: angrybirds sticks to some of its roots... SOME, but has also really been defined and tweaked to near perfection; animation is fantastic; the levels are challenging; and the gameplay takes about 3 seconds to pick up.  The new features are also pretty sweet, like the spells and arena. All adds to the game's replay ability.  However, like most people have already said, Rio have really sold out and made a game HEAVY on in app purchases and ads...   This sort of thing would not normally be an issue (for me) but it really grinds my gears that at times it literally stops you from being able to play unless you spend money to buy gems for extra lives. Wanna hit the replay button like old times? Oh no, that's long gone. Say hello to the fancy new \give up\" button that will cost you a life, which will be replenished in half an hour. Oh, did I also mention that you only get 5 lives anyway?  Well, just in case - you only get 5 lives which will easily be eaten up in a few merciless moments when you hit one of the many tough levels on offer. Rio are still good at this, which is great. Not so great when you're not the best gamer, or a minor that does not have access to a freaking bank account. Or both. I'm neither of these things, but am still having issues.  do not get me wrong, you're not made to stop playing all the time, oh no, you can always watch a nice long add for some second rate crappy game in exchange for a free bird or life. Thanks Rio, for a moment there, I was worried I would not be able to keep going, but thanks to your brilliant ad placement, I can have an extra whack at this tough level, and also be enlightened about Paradise Island or whatever the hell the crappy ad was about.  Seriously, why can not we just pay a fixed, one off payment like old times (I'm sure most  angrybirds fans would not object) and be free to play for however long we want without having more media and advertising crammed down our throats? If Rio did this, but still kept the in app purchases as an option, I'm sure there are still many that would spend their hard earned cash for extra spells and gems.  Great game, but horribly tainted and at times, ruined by the above points I have ranted about.   Right, it's been half an hour, let's have another go at this level..."

oh no, that's long gone. say hello to the fancy new \give up\" button that will cost you a life, which will be replenished in half an hour. oh, did i also mention that you only get 5 lives anyway?  well, just in case - you only get 5 lives which will easily be eaten up in a few merciless moments when you hit one of the many tough levels on offer. rio are still good at this, which is great. not so great when you're not the best gamer, or a minor that does not have access to a freaking bank account. or both. i'm neither of these things, but am still having issues.  do not get me wrong, you're not made to stop playing all the time, oh no, you can always watch a nice long add for some second rate crappy game in exchange for a free bird or life. thanks rio, for a moment there, i was worried i would not be able to keep going, but thanks to your brilliant ad placement, i can have an extra whack at this tough level, and also be enlightened about paradise island or whatever the hell the crappy ad was about.  seriously, why can not we just pay a fixed, one off payment like old times (i'm sure most  angrybirds fans would not object) and be free to play for however long we want without having more media and advertising crammed down our throats? Comments: angrybirds has always been fun and addictive. This new version brings life into the series with fresh animations (if only it was 3D), new boss levels, new birds and new powers, amongst other things.  Unfortunately there is only one drawback; a finite amount of lives. What made  angrybirds so addictive was the ability to play none stop, or without having to wait a long time for a life to return to us. Of course an unlimited option is available but, of course, for a price. Nobody likes to have to do this, and I understand a company needs to make money, but ultimately they will lose on this if they do not invoke a one off price for unlimited fun.  It still gets a 3/5 from me, the game is still very exciting to play and I can be patient with the lives coming back, but I will not be coming back to it as often as I would if it was like its predecessor.
lower_comments: angrybirds has always been fun and addictive. this new version brings life into the series with fresh animations (if only it was 3d), new boss levels, new birds and new powers, amongst other things.  unfortunately there is only one drawback; a finite amount of lives. what made  angrybirds so addictive was the ability to play none stop, or without having to wait a long time for a life to return to us. of course an unlimited option is available but, of course, for a price. nobody likes to have to do this, and i understand a company needs to make money, but ultimately they will lose on this if they do not invoke a one off price for unlimited fun.  it still gets a 3/5 from me, the game is still very exciting to play and i can be patient with the lives coming back, but i will not be coming back to it as often as i would if it was like its predecessor.
